Could have gotten a much more satisfying meal closer to home that was special for half the price. I guess it's all about location. The host was the best part of the experience. Very welcoming and accommodating was he. If you're going to pay that much, there's much better places to go downtown.
Best bartenders, managers, hummus, tomato bisque & vodka waters in the city ;) say hi to bartender Tommy and Manager Scott. They're the bestest.

Yes, there is a d-bag factor here. HOWEVER, I am here to write that redemption can happen. And Tavern on Rush redeemed itself in my eyes. I didn't have plans to ever return, but stuff happens... First, I screwed up our reservation and made it for the following day. They were obviously busy, and somehow still got us a table for five within two minutes. Upstairs we went. Okay wine list. Our meals were pretty darn good. Oysters weren't the best, but I don't have the highest expectations for GREAT oysters in the midwest. My colleague and I split the lobster risotto and some buttery fish I can't remember the name of now, special. Thumbs up. We went downstairs to hang at the bar, and yes, the area does retain it's "Viagra Triangle" namesake. Ran into a couple jerks at the bar who seemed to be regulars, but other than that a great re-experience overall. I disagree with John H. I am a Miami native, and this place is NOT like the tourist traps there. Yes, it caters to tourists as it's a block away from all of the hotels. But it is definitely NOT to be compared to those places in South Beach.

The dinner menu is impressive. I started with the most expensive martini. The espresso martini. It was strong and rich. The bread basket is TOO good. Dont fill up on it. Best bread assortment ever. I had the olive crusted swordfish served over scalloped potatoes. It was prepared just right. The tomato bisque soup was so cheesy and served piping hot.  Side note. Service was sub par. For the money we were spending, he was inattentive and indifferent.  But I'd go back for the bread basket.
Great people watching.  Very professional bar tenders.  Fun spot to hang out

Lunch date with my new Chicago BFF, alfresco! Both nursing mid-week blues & back to back late nights- we were in need of good fare & solid eats, Tavern totally nailed it. Seriously tender calamari (offered fried or seared) and iced tea got us off to a good start . The "312" salad with blackened shrimp was awesome, minus the slightly bland dressing.  And her BBQ chicken sandwich was so good I wanted to stab at it for multiple samples without permission! Malinda our server was a doll. Gave us a slight discount for the untypically slow service  that day. All served piping hot- just like I like it!

My parents were coming to town for the day, and they requested an outdoor dining place for dinner.  Tavern was my immediate thought, as its location offers such beautiful ambiance and a great opportunity for people-watching.  We arrived about 7:30 on the Saturday evening, and were quoted a 45-min wait.  This is a lengthy wait for my parents (and most people!), but it was a beautiful night and we thought we'd be able to entertain ourselves in the area while we waited.  We sat in the park across the street for a half hour, and then checked back with the hostess to see how things were moving.  She suggested that we move inside to the bar, as our name was close to the top of the queue and she would be coming to find us shortly.  We were excited that the wait may be shorter than expected.  While we stood inside, 20-30 parties were called.  I checked in with the hostess several times, thinking we must have missed her call.  Each time, she said "very close," "just a few minutes more."   We ended up waiting close to two hours.  We were exhausted and over hungry.  I could hardly read the menu I was so aggravated.  The waitress greeted us, apologizing that she'd heard about our grueling wait. I was surprised that our situation had been recognized, but that nothing was offered to us in return.  I would think that they would at least throw us a free dessert.  The setting was beautiful, and the food truly delicious, but honestly so hard to enjoy after what we were put through.  We couldn't even order the wine we had hoped to get, as my parents would have to drive home immediately after the meal.  After the meal, I noted on the check that our wait was excessive, and the waitress kindly asked the manager to speak with us.  He listened intently, and after even MORE waiting, he asked if he could credit us something on our bill.  We really just wanted to leave.  It was 11 o'clock and my parents had a 2 hour drive ahead of them.  We thanked him for the offer and left.

Found this place by accident, trying to find some late night bar/grub after a movie.  I am obviously not from around here (only my second time in Chicago) and I was driving around with some friends exploring.  I Was surprised to find what I now know as the Viagra Triangle.  There are sooooo many reviews on people watching, saw all these reviews after the fact...  Well first off, we weren't planning on going to an upscale place, it just kind-of happened when we saw this.  Obviously, because of this, the people watching was AMAZING.  I mean, seriously to be blunt, some of the hottest women I have ever seen we saw in the 1.5 to 2 hours or so we were here...waitresses, customers, people walking, etc.  On a side note, I want to mention that even though this was 'upscale' place nobody gave us a hard time for what we were wearing (shorts, t-shirts, etc) although we kind-of stood out... no one thought otherwise and we appreciated that.   About service and food?  Being late night, we had the dumb down bar menu, of course.  But the food was pretty darn good, but slightly expensive for what you get (know what your getting into).  Our waitress served us well, especially when it was pretty busy...we didn't have any problems.  I would love to come back.
My favorite when out on the viagra triangle. Excellent food and bar.

we were well waited on by Chelsea. Good food, great service. I am mostly writing this review about Chelsea who looks like a walking example of Photoshop except she's real & combine that with sweet intelligent pleasant personality. I'm sure throughout the night she is hit on and messed with ad nauseum, yet manages to stay classy and cool. Hang in there Chelsea. You are a class act.

Over-hyped steakhouse.  A seen and be seen kind of place.  Drinks are expensive, food is expensive but everyone already knows that.  We sat outside and watched all the old men gawk at the young, artificially enhanced women.  Our waiter was very snooty.  I know I'm dining in a fancy, expensive restaurant, I don't need your attitude with my meal.  Several in our party ordered the fillet Oscar, it was delicious.  I had the crab cake, it was huge but not the best crab cake I ever had.  We had the orange creme brulee for dessert, it was to heavy on the orange liquor.  Nothing much new to say on this place.  If you want an expensive meal, with lots of people watching, this is your place.
1 of the Best brunch spots in the loop 5stars breakfast burrito yummy egg bennys!

Cash Money and I wanted brunch, oh yes we did , after a week of Blueberry Smoothies for breakfast we had a hankering for a real dogs breakfast. Fortunately my good friend Auntie Fabulous was available so I suggested we amble up to the Gold Coast to find a us a dog friendly spot.  Apparently 7000000000 other residents of the Viagra triangle decided the same action was in order. Faced with long waits at all of the restaurants that would accept Cash Money loitering on their patio... we decided to try out Tavern on Rush and whoo boy am I glad we did.  First of any one who reads my reviews knows I am a freak about good service. After being seated under an umbrella ( YAY) we were promptly watered ( DOUBLE YAY) and a very nice waitress offered up menus and took drink orders. I dithered around about ordering a Bloody Mary because i am afraid of them always being too spicy. She assured me that it would not be and amazing -it was a balanced flavorful, lightly spiced, nicely vodka'ed up glass of morning goodness.  We took forever to order our food, waffling between classic breakfast staples and some interesting variations. Our server was SO PATIENT and really let us take our time.  Auntie Fab had the blueberry marscapone stuffed brioche French Toast with a side of sausage, I had a spicy skirt steak on corn tortillas with perfect scrambled eggs on the side. My only minor fuss was that the pieces of steak were too big for the tiny tortillas and they rapidly fell apart - leaving me to eat with a fork - not a tragedy, but probably not what the presentation intended.  We shared a huge plate of PERFECTLY ripe in season fruit. ahhhhhhhh. But truly what made this a super lovely way to while away a Sunday morning was the attentive, relaxed service, so thank you red haired charming uber helpful, non stress inducing waitress.. you are a gem and Tavern on Rush is too!

Tarven On Rush makes me feel "missing" - you know, huge boobs that go up to your neck, tight dresses, big "bling" watches, money, range rovers, sport cars, dark eyeliners, extra make-up, etc... Oh the things I don't have in life.  But their foods are good - with decent portion too. Great location with nice outdoor seating. We stopped by during a busy time without reservation and the hostess was nice enough to sit us within 10 minutes.  And yes while I feel like I'm "missing" certain things - the people watching, like every other reviews has mentioned, is very fulfilling. Check it out yourself.

Great Location, especially since the weather was perfect and we sat outside.  The server seemed overwhelmed and was slow to complete each task.  My tuna was good, but my boyfriend's steak was tough and disappointing.  Compared to other restaurants we've been to nearby, for the same money you can get a better meal and better service.

Went to Tavern on Rush Saturday night and found it to be pretentious as always and we love it that way!  The meat market attitude is better than ever and it is still the place to see and be seen in Chicago in the summertime.  Well dressed men chasing after beautiful women (both young AND old) as well as out of towners trying to get a front row seat to people watch.  We knew it would be a good night in the bar when we saw a Bentley, Maserati, and Audi R8 parked out front.  A lot of local celebs hang out there too.  There always seems to be a lot of cougars on the prowl and Saturday did not disappoint.  My wife got hit on twice going to the ladies room!  The food is great too but usually secondary to the "circuses".  The layout of the bar is very good and the outdoor seating can't be beat for enjoying a summer night in Chicago.  Be sure to try the Oysters.
Great people watching

My cousin lives across the street, so every so often we come here for drinks. I think about it this way, I get to pay a very expensive surcharge to do some good people watching while no longer being thirsty.

I'd give it 4 stars for our perfect table that was surrounded by floor to ceiling windows.  The people watching was great and the martinis were ok but not inventive or exciting and I thought French martinis went out with lip plumper?

It's somewhat weird to grant this place 4 stars after reviewing EL with the same. Call it Affirmative Action, or just plain "what it is," but this review goes to show a $13 omelette and a $125 meal can both be spot on. Essentially, Tavern on Rush is like the Cheesecake Factory's private-school counterpart, just with a smaller menu. It has excellent people watching, an "everything looks good" menu, nice service, and a great location. I celebrated my 25th birthday with 6 girls here and all I have to say is props-to-them for sticking with us, as I can only imagine our level of obnoxious rivaled that of a Friday Night bachelorette party on Division Street. They even brought me a piece of complimentary chocolate cake that was the size of a new-born baby. Not willing to risk ill-fitting jeans later in the night, I reluctantly had to pass on more than a bite of the thing, but I sincerely appreciate the gesture.

I have always loved this place, from the day it opened and I was living in the neighborhood back in 1990somethings.  Yes, it's a meat market and yes, it's crazy expensive but I just really miss having places like this nearby now that I live in my sleepy suburban town.  I love the Sinatra/Fitzgerald/Bennett tunes and the dark woods and the swagger and style of the place.  It's very masculine, very old school, very Chicago.  Love it, love it, love it. I recently re-visited for a night cap and appetizer after a networking event in the City.  I was by myself at the bar which is sometimes awkward for a woman of a certain age or any age, really.  But the bartender was welcoming and friendly and I checked in on Facebook and saw that half the bar had already checked in.  Which I found sort of amusing.  The bartender recomended the crab cake and it was undoubtedly the best I had ever eaten.   Headed back to my sleepy little suburb somewhat begrudgingly.  But I will be back again and again.

Outdoor seating is wonderful. Although people CAN smoke, so just know that before u sit outside. I am a steak lover & I know where the best steak restuarants are. I was pleasantly surprised when I had their filet. It was great!!!!!!! The neighborhood isn't my cup of tea, or the clientelle. But that's not the restaurants fault. All in all,  our service was good & the food was good.  :)

Pros: nice decor.   Cons: Boring, overpriced Viagra Triangle food. Service was indifferent. The quality of bread is usually a good predictor of the meal to come.  Bread was stale and so was the rest of the meal. Tuna tartar  was under-seasoned and slathered in guacamole.  Pizza was terrible.  I can't remember the rest of the meal. . .Ordered a vodka martini and got gin.
I love this place for brunch on Sunday mornings.  It is so relaxing to sit outside with friends and family.  The food is great and the brunch food is very well priced.

Shame on you, Tavern on Rush--you enticed me with your delicious online menu.  You lured me in with your delicious smell and your classy ambiance.  And then you crushed me dreams by providing me with the worst waitress I've had in a long time.  She was so bad that our party of four had to leave. We got there around 6 on Saturday.  We found a table in the bar aread for four--score!!  The waitress came around....once....the whole time.  No, I am not kidding.  She took our drink order (two waters, a coffee, and a coke), and then left.  Someone else delivered the coffee.  We flagged down a different waitress TWICE to ask for menus (which we NEVER received).  We flagged down a different waitress who finally was able to send our waitress over with the check because we were not going to spend another DIME in that place after being there for 45 minutes with no menu, no food, and no waitress. Luckily Morton's steakhouse was able to take the $250 we dropped on dinner.  And they were happy to do it!

I live a few blocks away and I still haven't made it here for any meal other than weekend brunch but let me tell you their brunch is delicious! My roomate and I stopped in here with her mom when we were first looking at apartments and now we can't stay away. The place has plenty of seating, both indoor and outdoor as well as friendly and attentive service. And, oh yea, the food is DELICIOUS.  I've tried a couple of things but 9 times out of 10 I get the eggs lola... an egg scramble with chorizo and pesto, seriously delicious.  Only "ehhh" brunch meal I've gotten there was the breakfast pizza which was just a little too out there for me

Almost average food at way above average prices. A decibel level that terrorists use to extract confessions. Long waits.  If you could book a table on the runway at O'Hare Airport you would have a more charming time.

Day 1 of vacation after a grueling conference meant lazy morning, slow start.  Needed a chill place to have a leisurely lunch and found the perfect spot.   We were seated near the window upstairs since it was too chilly and rainy for outdoor seating.  Great spot to people watch on the street.  Ordered the Tavern chopped salad and grilled cheese sandwich to share with a friend.  Grilled cheese was decadent, having only half and complementing with a salad was the perfect, not overly indulgent but completely satisfying mix.   Service was attentive and friendly, I'd come here again.

Stay away.  I visited Tavern on Rush 5/12/2011.  The service was atrocious (30 minutes to order a drink, and 2 hours to get entrees that weren't even correct).  Mixed drinks ordered "up" are doubles, so your typical Manhattan is $20.   It's really too bad--this place is in a great location.  Sadly,  they simply don't care about customer service.
Here on vacation. Excellent steak and potatoes. Pasta carbonara not so great.

This is a decent place to grab a drink on Rush.  The menu items seem a bit pricey,   Came here for drinks and apps. We had some crab and artichoke soub and crab and artichoke dip that were both very good choices.  We also tried the fillet mignon sliders which didn't come close to meeting expectations.  they lacked taste and were cooked more medium than medium rare like we had asked. This place is definitely a pretty good spot to grab a seat and do some people watching as pedestrians walk by on rush. A nice bonus is that the waitresses they hire are smokin' hot.
Great food, great service, great location. Wednesday nights are prime rib night.   One of the best steakhouses in Chicago. Look forward to going back and would recommend this place to anyone!

Solid place. I had the homemade noodles and prawns. Tasty sauce and yummy noodles. My host had the veal chop which was also very good. The au gratin potatoes were very average, but the bread was awesome and the service was top notch. Very much recommend.

Went here for the Sunday brunch and food was very good----however the waitress we had was lacking. She failed to retunr to our table after the food was served til it was time to collect payment. We had to flag down a busboy to get another cup of coffee and more hot water for our tea. Then the ultimate faux paux---I had leftover french toast and wanted a doggie bag---she threw it out!!! Had to ask the bus boy again because she never returned with it and when she did , she said---well, I saved you a few calories!!!  The nerve!!  She finally offered to have the chef make "one" slice but it would take 15-20 min. FORGET IT!!  Don't know if I would go back!!

I hate having to write this review, because the steak here really is very good, in fact, possibly some of the best I've had. However, the rest of the food we had on our most recent visit greatly overshadows the excellent steak. SP and I eagerly went on the last Sunday of Oyster Fest, excited to partake in $1 oysters. We ordered a dozen raw on the halfshell, 4 of each kind that was available. When the oysters arrived, not only did they look unappetizing, but they appeared to have a sickly yellow-greenish tinge. The oysters had remnants of what looked liked seaweed (gosh I hope that's what that was) and some of the shells had barnacles on them. If the oysters had tasted fresh, we may have been able to forgive the troubling appearance, but not only were the oysters lacking any liquor (not the alcoholic kind) inside their shells, they were poorly shucked, with bits of shell all over the place, and tasted like they were fished out of the garbage instead of the ocean. The oysters were neither plump and juicy nor briny, but instead, oddly shriveled and tasted the bad kind of "fishy". Granted, these were $1 oysters, but a restaurant of this caliber cannot expect to serve garbage like this and maintain any sense of dignity. Aside from the god-awful oysters, we ordered the hot artichoke and crab dip which was just "meh", the 312 salad with salmon which SP really liked, and the petit filet with a blue cheese crust, which was excellent. The steak was tender enough to but cut with a butter knife, cooked medium rare just as we requested, and not overly salty.  One last gripe: The bread basket. I happen to be one of those people that really, truly look forward to the bread basket. There is nothing better while waiting for your food than warm, freshly baked bread with butter and a glass of red wine. The bread basket came out filled with promise, but I was sorely disappointed with each and every item in there. Each piece of bread was cold and tasted like it was purchased earlier in the week from the bakery section of a supermarket. I mean, the least you can do is warm it up and make it appear as it just came out of the oven, you know? Maybe our experience was an anomaly, but it was still the worst $150 dining experience we've ever had. The steak was great, however, and that's the only thing that saved this from being a 1-star review.

This place is damn good. I was really impressed. The servers and bartenders are awesome. The bartender the night I went made me a drink he called the John Daly. It was Lemonade and Ice Tea (aka Arnold Palmer) and Vodka. What a thing!? I was also delicious. I went with one the salads off the menu and that was awesome. The lettuce was so fresh and as I recall everything in it was so tasty. I'm not sure what the dressing was, but that was so good as well. The atmosphere is a bit nicer inside, and I felt bad for being dressed down a bit. I enjoyed my time here and the cool guy in the bathroom with cologne and gum. Fun stuff. Not cheap though, but worth it if you can.

We came here this past Friday night for the $1 oysters at the bar. The oysters were very good, especially the oyster rockefellers. They were decent in size and very fresh. We also ordered the pizza, and it was delish! The drink menu was pretty standard, I had a glass of prosecco for $10 bucks and a glass of wine for $8. Both I thought were reasonably priced. My boyfriend had a martini and it was made very well. I have been here on several other occasions for dinner and the food has always been good.  The scene is outstanding for people watching. The older men are always trying to pick up the younger women ;) We had a great time sitting at the bar, sipping on our cocktails and watching the night unfold. It tends to be a bit of an older crowd, with a mix of younger woman. It was a perfect Friday night happy hour spot, and we would definitely go back for the $1 oysters!

So, it looks like I need to stop being dragged here for drinks and just sit down and eat. Until then, I'll have to review the atmosphere, drinks, and bar area.  Here It goes:  It's pretentious.  It's crowded.  It's about being seen.  It's full of rude people.  It's great for drinks.  It's in the V Triangle.  It's doable.  It's Tavern on Rush.

Been meaning to write this for a while.  Tavern on Rush is a great place for any meal of the day.  Their breaksfasts, lunches and dinners are  great, and the variety is nice when you're with a family or a group.  When the weather is nice, eating outside is awesome.  The people watching experience can't be beat!   Sometimes upstairs in good weather, they'll seat you near the open windows.  It's a little bit of heaven!

I've eaten at Taveron on Rush twice now and have enjoyed both experiences thoroughly. Great location. Everything on Rush St. is fun and carries a vivid ambiance to it. The main dining area is located upstairs which has a classy feel too it. And there is also a fairly large bar area on the first floor that is usually pretty upbeat with customers. Obviously parking can be a problem but as usual I'd suggest taking advantage of the valet service. Although it was busy and I had forgotten to make reservations, we were seated within the first 10 minutes of arriving.  The food here was above average, but not anything too outstanding. Me and my date shared a shrimp cocktail (her idea) which was good and came with 6 or 8 massive shrimp. I enjoyed a chicken parmasean, and she had a steak. Everything was generously portioned and I barely finished my meal. The wine was great and was genuinely priced. Nothing too extreme. Price tag was a little high, but given the location (Rush St.), and the fairly well dining experience, I wouldn't say it was abnormally high. Overal a solid experience at Tavern on Rush.

This is a Chicago kinda place.   If you have guests from out of town, you can make everybody happy with their variety-packed menu.   The patrons themselves are actually an entertaining crew---most are more consumed with trying to impress each other with their Brooks Brother's suits and their pulled-tight face lifts than actually eating.  It has a "old boy's club" or "cheezeball Chicago-mafia" kind of vibe. The maitre d's name is Benny and he has been working there FOREVER.  Just tell him your uncle Vinny from Cicero used to play cars with him and he will get you a good seat.:) The lounge downstairs has live music sometimes, so it can get loud. I recommend the tavern Chopped salad---They took it off the menu, but have them make it for you anyway.  They will.  Just tell 'em "Julia said so!" (with confidence, so they think it might be Julia Roberts.) Grab an over-priced glass of wine, relax and soak in the "desperate housewives of the midwest" scene.   If you are a cute girl, you won't even have to buy the glass of wine.  A elderly male patron (who might mistake you for a call girl) will probably send one over with a wink.    Seriously.  Not making that last one up.

Naturally I come to Tavern on Rush, like everyone else, for the people watching.  I come to see crazy age-differences of couples,  I come to see botox at it's finest, I come to see if I can spot a celebrity. I'm sure no one actually comes here for the food and drinks.  Because, if you did, you should really go next door to LuxBar or Carmines.  But if you come for the people-watching....jackpot!

The food is delicious and reasonably priced. My favorites include tomato basil soup (better than any I've ever had), margarita pizza ( made in wood burning oven) and the filet oscar. YUM!! Don't forget to split the big cholcolate cake. And I mean it when I say split. The piece has about 6 tiers and is enough to feed 4 people.

So I went here with a group and the appetizers everyone had were amazing. The entrees should have been made by the same guy. The meat here is good but the pasta wasn't anything special. And seeing all the young women with old guys was interesting. I suppose that area earns it's title of Viagra triangle. It's worth a try.

I guess "underwelmed" would best describe my experience at TOR.  When you're situated at Chicago's version of "Hollywood and Vine", the expectations are already sky high.  In my view, reality doesn't measure up with the hype. Food:  Not too bad but not as outstanding as one would expect. Service: Adequate but with a bit of an attitude on the two occasions I've dined there. Atmosphere:  5 stars.  If people watching is your thing, consider TOR "mecca". I'd go again but with more realistic expectations.  If you're expecting the best, you'll be disappointed.  If you're looking for a decent meal and a fun night in the city, you should be fine.

Since we both working and weren't able to be home for Thanksgiving, my sweetie surprised me and took me to Tavern On Rush. We were seated right away, and it was at a lovely table near the window overlooking the street. The food and the atmosphere made for a lovely Thanksgiving away from home. Our server was excellent and very well-educated in helping us choose the perfect bottle of wine to go with our tastes as well as with our dinner. We definitely left full and satisfied. The staff were friendly and sent us off with enough leftovers as if we were leaving from a relative's house! Don't let the high-end location fool or deter you. The staff really do understand and value the concept of customer service and how to make you feel welcomed. The location, Viagra Triangle, is not a usual haunt, but being there definitely made for some interesting, if not, humorous people-watching. It was good Thanksgiving entertainment!

I have never had a bad meal here. Definetly have reservations..or wait for 2 hours. Yes, expect Viagra Triangle Cheesyness,watch for granny with better legs than you! However I love sitting in the bar people watching before dinner. I have never been disappointed with anything I have had.. fish, chicken, lamb, burgers. All have been pleasing. I recommend this place to many visitors because of its location. Enjoy!

Went for a dinner date with the bf around Labor Day weekend to enjoy the last stretch of patio-eating days... We sat upstairs at the balcony and the atmosphere was tres bien! :) I had the oysters, and we shared the heirloom tomato salad. They were both awesome, definitely could taste the freshness of the ingredients! Then we shared the Chateaubriand, a filet mignon that was carved tableside along with perfectly grilled vegetables. The vegetables...oh gosh, they were SO good. Just as good as the steak, and I'm SUCH a carnivore! We also had complimentary dessert, which were delicious but we were too full to devour them as much as we would've liked... Tiramisu was decadent as it should be and the mango sorbet was good...a bit diluted for my taste. Tavern on Rush was definitely a good Chicago experience, would love to go again!

Food is good, atmosphere is great, server was awesome-hostess was HORRIBLE. On the evening that me and seven of my friends chose to enjoy the outdoor seating at Tavern we we initially sat at one table.  When we requested the table next to us as well, due to the expectation of a larger group, we were told that we could have the table-with a two hour limit. Mind you-this wasn't a night club with bottel service expectations, nor was there a wait for outside seating.  After inquiring with our server, who was happy to take our orders and allow us to divide and conquer the bill later; he disclosed that he was told of no such thing.  We simply went for the atmosphere or winding down on a Friday evening and people watching on one of the last warm weather evenings of the season.  I was sure to correct the hostess (who by the way failed to mention this standard to any other guests that she sat around us) on my way out the door.  I could have called it discriminatory, I could have asked to speak witht he manager and complain.  But I chose to write it here.  Still love the food and drinks and openess, and would go back.

loved it! was with a group of 20!!! food came out fast and HOT-- had the crab cake eggs bennidict(sp?)-- amazing! service was top notch and on top of every need at a huge table! we all were very pleased with our visit! will go again!

You know those guys who drive big, flashy SUVs/trucks who are compensating for 'something else'? This restaurant, although flashy and attractive on the outside, is compensating for their less-than-mediocre service and bland menu.

Tavern always has solid food but now that I've tried a few other items on their menu, I've realized they do some things better than others. Had another lovely brunch here with my friend. I ordered the Cobb salad which was excellent except for the fact that my avocado wasn't sliced and was just a big chunk sitting on top. Avocado vinaigrette dressing was unique and tasty (you can never have enough avocado).  My friend ordered the the Oak Street Scramble (ground turkey, goat cheese, spinach, sun-dried tomatoes, mushrooms, and potatoes) but she wanted fruit instead of potatoes and we were charged $2 for the substitution, which I think is ridiculous! Try eating healthy and you get charged more, that's nice. I had a taste of the scramble and it was decent but I still prefer the breakfast burrito. Service could have been better, but that won't deter me from coming back.

Tavern is right down the street from my house and always a safe bet.  It really doesn't require a long review so I'll keep this short and sweet. Food - good, upscale bar food.  highly recommend the brunch, its fantastic. Atmosphere - classy. outdoor seating allows for great people watching. there are loads of freaks in the triangle. Service - decent. my only complaint is that the girls that work here think they don't have to be nice because they are somewhat attractive.  since i'm not a 55 yr old man, i guess they're not interested.   all in all, can't go wrong with tavern.  a definite staple in my book.

Several of my Chicago contacts said nightlife downtown is all about Rush Street. Just go. So I went. Twice. The people watching in the Viagra Triangle is fabulous. And although Tavern on Rush wasn't the most exciting choice, we were treated very well here. From being greeted warmly at the door to a server that was on top of it, the vibe was just right. Mr. K and I are both big time sports fans, so the bar was a fantastic place to watch a game.  The bar was decorated for the holidays (dug the dancing witch with the glowing eyes) and pleasantly packed with people. Enough so there was a buzz in the air, but you could still have a conversation. A bachelorette party was going on at one table and there was a nice mix of business folks in their 30s, 40s and 50s on bar stools and lounge chairs. The drinks, coffee and dessert were fine.

I stopped in for lunch and sat at the bar, and was really disappointed.  First off their beer selection was limited and they were out of a couple of choices.  I asked the bartender what he recommended and he suggested the sirloin steak sandwich, which I paired with the crab bisque.  The soup was bland and the sandwich was a sloppy mess of a meal.  The overall experience had highlights equal to the Cubs postseason play the last 101 years. There are much better places to go in that part of town.

It is safe to say I will not be returning to the Tavern On Rush after my experience this past weekend. We came in expecting a wait after not having a reservation and were told (very pretentiously might I add) it would be a little over an hour.  We decided to head to the bar and have a few drinks while we waited (no real problems yet). The restroom attendant in the basement was not only having a personal conversation that did not stop while I was there (and had to step between to wash my hands), he was openly counting his cash the entire time I was in the restroom. We waited for over 2 hours before I asked the host how much longer we could expect to wait. We were told we were next, and yet a few minutes later, another reservation was called and we continued our wait for another 20 minutes before we were finally given a table (with another pretentious smirk by the host). From there the experience was fine. The food was good and the waitstaff was friendly (although I do not like to be made to feel guilty for NOT ordering dessert). This is the first time I have been anywhere where I felt impelled to write a review throughout my experience. I do not like to feel like I am being a burden to your hosts while I order $10 glasses of wine amongst the most confusing restaurant setting I have ever experienced. The music was notably bad (think late 90s pop radio), and the atmosphere seemed mixed with both upper class couples and bachelor parties. No thanks.

Great location, esp sitting outside to people watch.  Food is good too, not 5 star but good.  Their salads are large and fresh-can even share with two people, they are that big. Fun place for a group of people or just the two of you on a sunny day in Chicago.

Definitely a place to grab drinks and for awesome people watching.  Alot of geezers and fashionable youngins...hmmmm. It's in a happening spot so I'd come here if I'm shopping in the area or something and need a drink, but wouldn't go out of my way to spend money here.

Tavern on Rush is all about what you're looking for. If your scene is drunk business men in their 50s with much younger girls in skimpy outfits hanging on their arms or wannabe famous athletes, Tavern on Rush is probably the place for you.  I grew up across the street, and I definitely have mixed feelings about Tavern. The service is typically pretty lousy and I'd never stop by after dark, but for a lunch or brunch place in their neighborhood, Tavern on Rush is near the top of my list.  Favorite menu items: - Chicken Caesar Salad (don't skimp on the yummy croutons) - Tomato Bisque - Burgers - Asian Fusion Bowls

I have eatten here many times, including a few weeks ago, and I always have a fabulous meal.  I love to sit outside and enjoy all of the people watching!  The food is fabulous.  I usually like to order the special of the day.  Last time, it was filet kabobs and soft shell crab.  WOW!  Delicious! Good appetizers and desserts.  Fun atmosphere. Highly recommend!
Nice place for people watching if you sit outdoors (2 hour max.), but the food is underwhelming. We ordered the Greek salad and margherita pizza.
Excellent service, great outside seating, and the best eggs Benedict ever!

Tavern On Rush is one of those she she foo foo bars/restaurants. The crowd is about %90 white and mostly the business type. (at least the times I went). I wouldn't make a big deal outta race usually but being a black female Ive had some unfortunate experiences around the upper crusty. However my experience there was great. The drinks were AWESOME. The food was a bit greasy, but i was to tipsy to care by the time it came. The service was good though the food took forever. understandably because it was packed. Over all it in my opinion felt like any other bar/restaurant except with suits. (^_^) BTW I'm not gay but they had the hottest waitresses Ive ever seen! they were all amazons,thin and gorgeous.... I wonder did they do that on purpose???

I have been to both Taverns, Tavern on the Park, Tavern on Rush, Carmines, etc. I will say one thing right off the bat: Get the Shrimp Cipriani. It is a pasta in a red cream sauce with Jumbo shrimp. Literally, it will change your night and you will walk out smiling. Not bloated, just happily full. PRO's- *Outdoor seating in a georous area with amazing views at sunset *Their steaks and seafood are amazing. The jumbo shrimp are perfect and worth every penny. *Price looks high at first when you see the menu, but the food is definitely top quality. I was hesitant to order at first, but it really is a great value and you get what you pay for.  CONS- *soda refills aren't free. They come in a small bottle, which to me is silly for a place like this when you want to sit outside and have a soda after your dinner or something.. *They do get pretty busy during rush periods, so service is slightly slower than the average resturant...but that is to be expected on a saturday evening I think *waiting for a table could be awhile- waits of up to 2 hours sometimes for patio seating... get there by 6pm and you're safe- get there after 7pm and you're screwed. :( Overall, awesome food. Highly Reccommend.

First, let me say that I can't review the food as I never got mine but the service was so bad that we (and two other tables) walked out at the same time. We waited 15 minutes to place our order, another 10 to get the coffee and OJ (breakfast time) and then another 30 minutes after that we gave up and got our check and left. The service was dreadful, there were 3 hostesses standing at the podium, oblivious to the fact that tables were leaving all around. I can't say what the food is like but I don't plan on going back to find out.

Dear Tavern On Rush waitress: I was really looking forward to a decadent brunch with my boyfriend this morning.  We walked in to your restaurant happy, hopeful, and hungry, and left full yet frustrated. Why did you ignore us for such a long time?  You (not so cheerfully) served all of those around us, those who had come in after us, before hurriedly stopping at our table just to tell us you would be with us soon.  I know, I know.  You are busy!  I think devising a better system for yourself to make it to all of the tables would be wise.   When you finally arrived, you asked us if we were ready to order and said we needed a few minutes.  You turned on your heels to walk away; luckily, we shouted out, "May we have a few coffees, please?" before you were out of earshot.  When our coffees finally arrived, they did not come accompanied with cream and sugar, as is the coffee-serving tradition.  We had to ask (five minutes later) for some when you (finally) came back over to us.  A full five minutes AFTER that, we had to politely ask again.  Finally, my boyfriend stood up to walk over and ask you.  You continued to give a few people their checks and pour someone else's drink before giving us our cream and providing us with a very non genuine "sorry."   My boyfriend and I pride ourselves on our patience and cheerfulness when ordering at restaurants and talking to our waiters/waitresses.  Although we both bit our tongues, you brought us very close to our nerves' end.   Lastly, you brought over the wrong meal (about an hour after we walked in the door).  At this point we would have eaten anything.  Just please.  Give.  Us.  Food.  When our meals arrived, I will admit they were very good.  But the service just wasn't there. I hope this constructive criticism has provided you with some reason to change your servicing ways.   Sincerely, Sara P.S. How come we were the only table without those bread stick things?

1. The food is WAY below sub par. 2. The old geezer at the hostess stand (with unnaturally bleached whit teeth) needs to take  Customer Service 101. 3.  Other than these two major problems the place is so so. 4.  Ok, I will give them that the place has a nice atmosphere and good people watching.

That lone star is for the people watching. That's it. If you're looking for a place to people watch in Chicago, then look no further you've found the perfect place. If you want an enjoyable dining experience you may want to keep looking.  I came here on a Saturday afternoon, and we were sat outside with very little wait. I had a chicken caprese salad dish, which I was notified by the waitress was one of their specialty dishes. I don't think you should go around advertising dishes as being a specialty to the restaurant unless they are pretty good. This dish was not. The chicken was dry and flavorless and the fresh mozzarella was pretty much non existent. Speaking of non existent, the service is pretty bad too. The waitress we had was sweet and she got our orders right, but she was never around. I didn't get one refill the whole time we were there and we had to ask a bus boy to find her when we were sick of waiting for our check. I definitely think this is a restaurant that knows people will come because of its name and location, so they don't try very hard if at all to impress.

Came here on a weeknight with my good friend and her mom. My friend and her mom got the Azteca salad and I ordered a half order of Rigatoni. As side dishes, we got asparagus and baked sweet potato. Oh, first off, let me tell you how divine that baked sweet potato was. Honey was drizzled on top of it, and the texture was fantastic. The potato melted in your mouth, and it was huge in size and flavorful.  The salads came out on two HUGE plates, and my half order was seriously fit for two, maybe even three. HUGE rigatoni covered in meat sauce. It was absolutely great. The pasta was a little undercooked, but it was okay. I didn't mind at all. There was complimentary bread, and the rye was great. The service was good, and our waitress was knowledgeable and friendly.  The atmosphere here is very upbeat and lively, even on weekdays. I am so glad I got to come here! I always pass by wanting to come in, but this place seems great for a date or a casual dinner. Loved the food, will be coming back to try something new!

Best food, worst service ever! We were seated quickly upstairs by a manager after the hostess said it would take 45 minutes.  We got the cab Kendall jackson wine and the shrimp appetizer to begin.   I got the ginger tuna steak, my friend got the salmon, and my sister got the Chilean Sea Bass, which was good and buttery. My ginger tuna was tasty and came with wasabi, like a sushi restaurant. The worst part was the server, Marier was his name on the receipt. Despite ignoring us the entire time and never asking if the food was ok, he was very eager to bring the check.  It wasn't closing time so I didn't know what the rush was.  After bringing out the check and splitting it for us, he proceeded to stand about 2 feet away and stare at us until we signed our check.  My sister finished first and he came over abruptly to grab her check and tried to grab my friend's as well who told him she wasn't finished.  He then continued to stand 2 feet away and stare more, as I decreased his tip with each minute of his stare.  As soon as I closed the check book, he came over and grabbed my friend and my check and left.  I was a waitress and I know that is the rudest thing to grab someone's check before they have left the table, let alone even signed it.  What were we gonna do? run away from the bill? He had already swiped our credit cards. It didn't make sense and that is the rudest server in the world!

I came to Chicago for the first time this weekend in order to attend the Crossroads Guitar Festival on Saturday.  While I was there I managed to attend one Chicago restaurant at least, before being at the festival all day and night Saturday, and flying home early on Sunday.   We were originally hoping to get in at Rick Bayless' Frontera Grill, but they were totally booked.  Fortunately, we knew a couple of girls who live in the area who took us to this place. It's basically upscale casual American.  We were able to get a table for 6 very quickly, and the seating arrangement was quite comfortable and the service was good.  We didn't really get much food, and a lot of us weren't drinking because we'd already had a lot of wine and stuff earlier.  We basically just had a relatively quick meal with main courses. I had the 12 oz lobster tail, which comes with melted butter and a lemon wedge.  I felt like the lobster might have been slightly overcooked for my taste, but it was very good quality and tasted great with the melted butter and lemon.  It's nice having lobster without having to put in all that work. I also had a bite of the cheese pizza that some of the other people were sharing.  It seemed to be of the Chicago style thin crust variety, and I think I like that style based on how they did it.  I'd love to come back to the city, if not the restaurant, and enjoy the fine Chicago cuisine.  And this was a fine start to that.

My first time there with my sister and friend.   We couldn't decided where to go to eat.  It was suggested to us Tavern on Rush.  As, I walked in the main entrance, we were told the wait would be a 30 minute.   We walked over to the bar and order our drinks,   It was a busy night for a Tuesday.   The drinks were good.  The service at the bar was a bit slow but for a busy night, this is what I expected.  They called our names for dinner and to see the tables and booths around, it was sure amazing to me.  Again, it's my first time there.  The service was awesome, our waitstaff recommended fillet Mignon.  It tasted so good, my friends loved it.  We had dessert after wards and yummie.   I will be back.  My best friend will be in from Maryland and I can't wait to take her there.  The prices are about right.  Good fun and Good Food.
The food is great and the service is good but the real reason we go is for the outside seating in the summer. Great place to people watch and enjoy a little down time.

Food was great, but after trying to use a gift card from the restaurants owner was rejected for no good reason the dinner went from pleasant to preposterous.  Tonight my friend and I enjoyed an extremely delicious dinner at Tavern on Rush, even though the busser was surly and clearly didn't enjoy his job. His attitude was rude and off putting. Also I made the mistake of trying to pay with Phil Stefani Gift cards and was sorely rejected. Our waitress was very sweet and offered to bring the manager over, then didn't. Luckily I had money to cover the bill but unfortunately not enough to tip our server well. I don't understand how this restaurant is not included under the Phil Stefani Card name when on the website it shows that it is one of the brands restaurants? This is completely misleading and I feel duped.  As a consumer who receives a card as a gift, then looks up the Stefani brand online, and locating a list of restaurants under the brand; this card should work for every one of their  locations. Currently the labeling of this information is only located under the Gift Certificate link. This information should also be located under the restaurants link on the  sefanirestaurants.com  page. I am disappointed and feel completely used by a company that has such a great name in the Chicagoland area.  I really like the Stefani Brand so above all else this is a huge disappointment. Hopefully the management team will respond to me so I can give it the 3 stars it deserves!

I love this place, as it is in one of my favorite areas in Chicago.  Sometimes, though, the service is absolutely terrible.  All too often, I wait around for my order to get taken.  I understand that the place is extremely busy, but at least take my order! However, I must say that when the steak and pizzas usually come to the table, it was all worth the wait.  The prices are pretty average for this area, as you expect to pay a handsome amount to eat in the Viagra Triangle!

Not impressed. Yeah, when you go to a restaurant in the Gold Coast, it's gonna be busy.  But this was such a circle jerk, I could not even enjoy myself.  I went on a Tuesday night, it was so packed we couldn't get a table outside, and the inside of this place is a bore.  A bore, AND you can't hear yourself think.  How they they came up with that combination is beyond me.  When I came out and noticed that it said "An Exciting Restaurant," I almost laughed out loud.   Our server was barely around until it was time for her to give us the check and flip the table.   The Margherita pizza was sub-par.  How do you make a mediocre Margherita, god damn it?!  Their vodka tonics were decent but small. Sorry for sounding so belligerent, haha.  I just feel like I wasted my time.

I have been to this place four times.  Three times were fantastic and one was pretty bad.  I am forgiving for my bad experience there because it was at around 4pm and there must have been a transition going on in the kitchen from the Lunch to the Dinner staff because what we were served was DOGSHIT.  My steak was severely undercooked when I asked for it Medium.  My fiance got a salad and the avocados in it were rock hard.  We had to send back both dishes. I give it four stars though because my other experiences there have been great.  The bar on the ground floor is packed to the brim with MILFS.  It is a little overpriced as I once accidently ordered a glass of Moet and was charged $18.  Eating on the second floor is much quieter.  The bone-in filet is my go to MEAT and they do it perfectly here.  They also have the big bottles of Hacker Pschorr beer which is my favorite. I love the atmosphere here, but Gibson's across the street is definitely a better steakhouse.  I've heard the weekend brunch is good and there is a lot of outdoor seating.  I will check that out this summer FOSH.

Their Azteca Salad is one of my favorite things around. The avacado dressing is rich, creamy and delicious. Their Bloody Marys are also great. They have your normal Bloody Mary, but then they also have a special one. Ask for that one. It literally was an Italian BMT club mixed with tomatoe juice and vodka. It is also a great place to sit outside. It is right at a major crosswalk for foot traffic, so it gives you that great summery feeling with everyone alive around you.

I frequent the Tavern on the warmer days when it's nice to walk outside and stop in a neighborhood place, and have a nice lunch with a friend.  I have had the salads, the pizzas, the sandwiches, and even on a chilly day, some tomato soup.  This place isn't the best lunch spot around, but it's cozy and the food isn't bad, although I have had a few times when I wished I'd dined somewhere else.  I've had to send the food back before when it  was cooked wrong, and last time burned, but I'll still come back.  It's close and comfortable, and once you add a little salt, you're in business.  Although it wouldn't be a bad thing if the kitchen did it for you.

Came here on a whim with some coworkers for dinner and had a great time! Location is dead on for some great people watching. We sat outside for hours and had a great time. There was 4 of us and we split 3 entrees and it was PLENTY. I would ask for the bar-menu as well as it has some more reasonably priced items.

If you like cougars, this is a five-star establishment.  If you like models bringing you drinks, this is a five-star establishment.  If you like guys in their 50s, this is a five-star establishment.  If you like watching people who act and dress like they are in the mafia, this is a five-star establishment.  Outside dining in summer is awesome, as it is all over Chicago. Drinks are expensive, the downstairs bathroom can be a dangerous expedition if you've had too much to drink and people tend to dress flashier than I care for.  That being said, for me it's a good place to start out your afternoon or evening.   Also read Mike K.'s review on this thread.
great steaks and crab cakes.  Killer Manhattan.  We had a large group and it was great.

I laughed out loud when I saw that people who viewed Tavern on Rush also search "cougars viagra triangle."  That about sums up the people at Tavern and the surrounding area.  That said, I think Tavern is a great place to grab BRUNCH.  I am unimpressed with their dinner menu as I think there are better places in the city for the buck.  I am unimpressed with the dinner atmosphere because I am not an old man looking to take home some young girl or an older lady looking for young meat. Instead, I am a younger guy that enjoys sitting outside and enjoying kick ass brunches.  The bagels and lox here are insanely good and the portion is huge.  The pancakes are done to perfection (I would order two not four) and the waffles are solid as well.  Eggs are eggs so dont expect to be blown away but all in all I am a fan of what Tavern is offering.   If you go at night happy hunting.  If you go for brunch maybe I will catch you there.

I come here pretty frequently since I live within walking distance... they have good "staples"- soups, salads and sandwiches.  I'm not gonna comment too much on the atmosphere (enough people have done that previously)... I usually sit downstairs near the bar area, loving the window seats. Make sure you ask for a bar-menu, which they oftentimes "forget" to give customers.  I adore tomato-soup, and their bisque is one of the best I've found around here... except it can be hit or miss. For example, last time I went it was so incredibly salty, I didn't enjoy a single bite. Other times, it is the perfect comfort food: creamy and delicious- leaving me craving another bowl.  Salads are typical- again, last time I went the house-salad was just off. How do you go wrong with a house-salad?! The balsamic was disgusting, even my friend (who loves balsamic-anything) said the dressing was horrible. The burgers are HUGE- and are usually always o.k and big enough to split. Just make sure to ask for ketchup to come out with your order... or else by the time they bring it out to you, you probably would have finished your meal.   They have a cajun-y chicken sandwich which again is hit or miss. Sometimes it is heaven, and other times it is either completely bland, burnt or far too cajuny (i.e. literally scraping off the seasoning and its STILL too salty/spicy). For those of you with a sweet-tooth, they have this colossal chocolate cake. We usually take it to go, and it eat it over the course of two-days (yes, it's that big). It's perfect with a glass of milk.  Nutshell? If you're in the area, stop in for some food- you might catch them on a good day.  Side-Note: Despite having a completely different menu, if you want consistently excellent food & service, check out Hugo's across the street.

Tavern on Rush can always be counted on for good food, a good place to meet up and an excellent source of people watching.  I have been here quite a bit, as of late, as it is the favorite meeting place of a couple of my friends. And why not? The service is good and we always get a great table by the window to people watch.  On a recent Saturday night (one of those rare winter days when the temps are pushing 50) there were even people sitting at the outside tables watching the throngs move by. I guess I shouldn't be surprised . . .as I was driving home- some guy had the top down on his car , , ,and my car thermometer said 38 degrees! Gotta love we midwesterners! There is both a bar menu and a restaurant menu. On this particular night I had the sea bass which was delicious! It was the daily special so it may not be there on your visit but it had some type of sauce on it with a little kick which made the entire dish sing!  Service was spot on considering the place was (as always) packed. Not a cheap date (my friend drank $90 alone in wine!) but the food is good and the drinks well poured.  Know that there is a bathroom attendant so take a dollar or two for Margaret, cuz I can't even imagine what it would be like to spend night after night in a bathroom, but she keeps it clean with a smile on her face!  But the most fun of the place? You just never know who is going to be hanging out there. Hockey players who are in town for a game (Go Detroit!), their crazy fans, old guys trying to be young, young girls trying to . . .(well, we never did figure out what they were doing) . . . .you name it, they are there. And watching it all is the most fun of all!

I've only eaten in the bar but everything I've had so far is really good. The bbq chicken pizza is awesome and so are the mini filet mignon burgers. The drinks are expensive but it is the gold coast so you have to expect that. Fun atmosphere for happy hour and late night. There is a good mix of young and old so it's a good place to people-watch.

I like my men like I like my steaks - aged. And at Tavern, I get both. Chicago Restaurant Week was an excellent opportunity for a bunch of recent college grads to try out a fancy place like Tavern on a budget. For $32 we feasted on: assortment of fresh, gourmet breads including a doughy and chewy foccaccia that was to die for, tomato bisque with a large bread crouton covered in cheese and fresh basil (or a salad with walnuts and blue cheese), steak with mashed potatoes and a cajun spice shrimp, and a chocolate bundt cake with dulce de leche ice cream (or cheesecake or tiramisu).  The soup was hands down the best part of the meal. It was perfectly pureed, not chunky. It was served piping hot which is how I like my soup. And the tiny pieces of fresh basil were like little flavor crystals bursting in my mouth. It really added some wonderful flavor to the dish.  The wine list was extensive and they had about 12-15 reds by the glass. My California Shiraz ran me about $9. Well worth it, as it was a great accompaniment to my steak.  I love the old school, boys club feel of this place. Perhaps because, well, I love the boys there. Except they're not boys, they're men.God I love the Viagra Triangle.

Came back again two nights later. Got the bone in filet this time. It was so much better than the ribeye.  They also used a different pasta for the mac and cheese, which was smaller and allowed for more cheese in each bite!  We had a larger group, so we ordered more sides. The onion rings were the bomb. BEST onion rings at a steakhouse ever!
Over priced and overrated. Cook your own steak and have a drink at Jillys but maybe I say this because Im a local.

Friday, February 12, 2010, reservations for two at 8pm. First, let me start out by saying Tavern on Rush was overall, a fantastic experience. I took my girlfriend there on a Friday night (before Valentine's Day), and selected this restaurant solely due to it having been recommended by two different friends as a reasonably priced restaurant near the John Hancock Observatory. I'll start off with the food... An assortment of bread (5-6 types) is brought to you as soon as you are seated. I love restaurants that do this. We then ordered the house salad with balsamic vinaigrette, which was fantastic, and I am not generally a fan of salads. For the main entrees, she got the seafood jambalaya and I got the Chris' Carbonara with chicken. Expect LARGE servings! We did not have room for dessert. Our waiter, Dariusz Lani, was extremely attentive and helpful in describing the dishes. Only complaint is that it is a little loud and lacks intimacy unless you get a booth (which we did). Nice interior and great location. Reservations recommended.

Pretentious? Maybe. Filled with an inordinately large number of people who belong in a J. Crew magazine? Pretty much. Consistently crowded? For the most part. BUT (this is a big "but") it is worth ignoring all of these things, and maybe waiting a while to be seated, to try their most excellent menu options.  I have been here three times now, and each time I've taken different people, and each time everyone in my party, including me, has left impressed. Their fare is typical American grub, but there is always a slight quirk to it that makes it memorable. I thoroughly enjoy the Chicken Sonoma salad when I'm there - the servings are plentiful, the chicken is always fresh and well seasoned, and the feta cheese, nuts and avocado dressing make it a exceptionally delish. Even the little toasted breadsticks are good, and that's saying a lot, considering they're just sticks of crackers.  The sandwiches and other salad options are also good choices - I really don't think you can go wrong here. The menu options aren't too pricey (keeping in mind the Gold Coast location, that is), so that's a plus too. The one downside is the soda - for some strange reason, they only have soda by the mini bottle, and those mini bottles don't last long if you're jonesin your caffeine fix.  So lack of caffeine buzz as I'm leaving is my only gripe. Otherwise, Tavern on Rush is a great lunch option if you're in the area (double plus that Anthropologie is directly across the street, but I digress....)

Went here for brunch on saturday, and the waitresses were in a corner talking.  my food came out cold and lousy..   i was also embarrassed because I brought people from out of town and bragged about the amazing food... unacceptable for a restaurant which boasts high standards.

excellent service - ordered the 2010 prix-fixe: soup of the day was chicken tortilla which had a nice kick as server promised. girlfriends were pleasantly surprised by the kobe meatloaf, well-seasoned. the skewered filet mignon with roasted vegetables and fettucinni all richly flavored.  only complaint was mediocre desserts - tiramisu was massive layers of mousse with minimal ladyfingers, faintly espresso. cheesecake nothing exciting.

Spent a recent Sunday afternoon at Tavern. The food was good and the people watching was definitely entertaining. The highlight and the reason I am writing this review is that we had an excellent server named Lauren that deserves to be mentioned. She was friendly and attentive and helped to make our lunch excellent with her wit, charm and sense of humor!
A couple martinis later I'm feeling like this is the greatest bar in town.  Good scene, good drinks, does the fun ever stop?  I'm not sure it does.

Tavern on Rush is such a classy restaurant, definitely an older crowd. When I went in September, I was able to get an outdoor table for two on a Sunday evening with no waiting which was great. I had the filet mignon which was small and pricey! But absolutely delicious and cooked perfectly. My boyfriend had the salmon which was also delicious too but I'm not a big salmon fan. Our waitress was a little slow, but overall I would give it a "B".

Despite the fact that my boyfriend and my combined ages would have equaled the age of every other patron at Tavern on Rush... and the fact that I enjoy being ogled by men twice my age in the bar area (not)... I will have to concede that Tavern knows how to cook an amazing (albeit expensive) steak. The Tavern Flatbread and "French-fried" Lobster appetizers were delicious, but oh wow... the steak was out of this world. Best seasoned/cooked steak that my boyfriend and I have had, although the portions were monstrous...we each could barely get through 1/4 of ours. Despite our $200+ tab, we'll definitely be returning, but next time we'll have to share a steak between the two of us!

By far the best place to eat outside in the summer, The food is great and the service is good, I love going here at night, the environment inside is great and the GM Benny is the nicest guy around, The cars that are parked outside sometimes makes you feel like your at a car show. he valet is kinda rude but that has nothing to do with Tavern I guess. Kinda pricey, but you shouldn't be eating out downtown if your BROKE!

Great for visitors on Sunday for Brunch! First place I went when I moved here for my favorite meal of the week! Sunday Brunch! Always looks packed. Everyone was very friendly! loved it cant wait to go back! Reminds me of an old favorite Old Ebbitt Grill back in DC, near the White House! Felt at home in this busy spot!

Tavern on Rush is located on Chi-town's famous Rush street near downtown/Gold Coast.  It seems to be quite the hot spot, yet filled with a lot of tourists.  They consider themselves an upscale Chicago steakhouse, which I'm sure it is, but I didn't try any food here.   The high on Saturday in Chicago was 7 degrees, so after walking around all day doing touristy type things, it was time to wind down and warm up with either a glass of wine or coffee and baileys.  The bar is huge, they have multi level seating, and large windows that boast an awesome view of the famous Rush Street.  Apparently in the summer time, they put tables outside and it turns into a large patio out front.   I took a look at the menu, but we were specifically going to get deep dish for dinner, so I passed.  They have a few different pizza options (which one in our party ordered and loved), a few sandwiches, salads, and pastas, and many prime steaks and chops.   One part of the menu which looked extremely appetizing and was hard to resist was the potato section of the menu!!  8 different potato options - baked, sweet, french fries, au gratin, mashed, loaded, twice baked, etc etc. YUM! I will definitely be trying one of these potato options if there is a next time. Service was good; music was terrible...The waitresses were all pretty hot and dressed skimpily hookerish (black mini skirts), but they got the job done!

As a bar, Tavern on Rush attracts an older crowd. Not that there's anything wrong with that, but 20-somethings might feel a tad out of place. But the atmosphere is very inviting and open with a bit more of a lounge feel. It's loud and busy so service suffers at night. They seem to be fairly lax on carding, too. I've kicked back and enjoyed a few rounds of drinks on many occasions. It's sort of my 'go-to' place when everything else is too crowded or I'm in a bad mood. As a restaurant, this place is definitely worth a visit. Breakfast is stellar and dinner is absolutely worth the price. The upstairs dining room is very pleasant and gives a great view. I recommend the pork chops and twice baked potato, though I hear good things about their pizzas (surprisingly).

I went here for a private party, so this review is based dining in a private room.  But it was fabulous!  The waiters were very attentive and friendly and the food was phenomenal.  I had the london broil and it was very tasty.  If you're looking for a private dining venue for a small group (under 20ish), consider Tavern on Rush.

While i am not a fan of the prices (12 bucks for valet, 6.41 for a goose island), i am not opposed to the crowd of cougars.   Really good time and would really like to keep coming here.    Though, i had some problems.   besides the price, it was overly crowded, the music is similar to that of any nightclub at first (think Green Dolphin, Sound Bar, and minus the salsa and big booming speakers), then it switches to stuff like Journey.  Make up your mind, do you want drunken people dancing there or not?   The bartenders were kinda snooty towards me.  As if they can't believe i am ordering a beer, and not something more expensive.   Hey, its my first time there, you want repeated service?   Be a bit more warm to newcomers.

I only come here to drink, so this review will be limited to the bar experience only.   First of all, have some cash in your pocket because the beers/drinks are rather expensive here.  Sometimes they will add on tax as well, making your bill for two beers come out to something like $12.76.  Different bartenders tend to charge different prices as well.  Interesting.  But anyway... You'll definitely be entertained by the crowd that patronizes this bar.  You will see the following: out-of-towners, cougars from the burbs, women 50+, "stripper" types, old married dudes, athletes and a few locals peppered in.  There are always over-the-top exaggerated types in here.  But the crowd is always interesting and entertaining.  You're going to have a laugh whenever you come in here.  Your chances of seeing a local celeb, athlete or visiting athlete are pretty high here.   The bathroom attendant here is one cool dude, even though he is a Sox fan.  The guy should really have a radio gig or something.  Flip him a buck or two. Service here is alright.  It's sometimes tough to get up to the bar for a drink.  The waitresses are almost all tall, thin and sultry.  I almost never sit down, so what they do beside parade around doesn't matter to me. Recommended for drinking and entertainment.

Great for people watching in the bar, but as far as dinner is concerned there are better places. I came here with a group of 6 for dinner on a Saturday night. To their credit, we were seating promptly at our reservation time and the service was excellent. But the food was just average. I had filet and it was good, not great. I think Joe's has a much better filet. My husband (who has eaten at just about every steak restaurant in the city) had the porter house and agreed. The rest of our party had fish and one of them had to send the ahi tuna back because it was so gross. Dinner was expensive and just really not that worth it.

I ate here with my brother for their Thanksgiving dinner. It was literally one of the most delicious meals I've ever had. Their squash soup was all the wonderful tastes of fall in one delectable bowl. Their turkey was great, and they had all the sides you could want for Thanksgiving: sweet potatoes, mashed potatoes, vegetables, stuffing, bread, and cranberry sauce. They offered free second portions, but what we had was more than enough. It was moderately expensive, but well under what many other restaurants charged and definitely worth it. I can't vouch for their everyday menus, but if Thanksgiving dinner was any indication, this is a wonderful restaurant.

With it being past 10PM, a girlfriend and I went walking along the streets of Chicago looking for a dinner after dinner meal.  We weren't necessarily starving, but definitely looking for food.  In the mist our search, we finally decided to walk no further - Tavern On Rush was open and was decided as our final destination.  (We really didn't want to continue walking anymore at that point! O__O)   With a pretty extensive steak menu, we opted to share a steak between the two of us.  It was either steak or seafood - and somehow, seafood did not seem like a good idea after 10pm.  In retrospect, we probably should have gone with the seafood.  With the recommendation and approval of our super friendly waiter, we ended up with a bone-in filet mignon with seasoned asparagus.  Service was superb - I couldn't have asked for better service, but I do wish to have asked for better steak. Our steak was decent.  But it was not melting-in-your-mouth-amazingness.  Along with our ice teas, our meals came out to be around $75!  $75 for decent steak? No thank you.  Definitely overpriced decent food.  We probably should have stayed down stairs in their bar lounge instead of going up stairs to their dinner tables.  Oh well, lived and learned.  Not returning.

One of the true "Viagra Triangle" institutions. Elder gents and younger ladies but not necessarily together. Some are ready to prey others are ready to be preyed upon. The waitresses are friendly but the bartenders are indifferent and don't smile or welcome you. The drinks are standard. I've eaten here a couple times. Skip the NE clam chowder. It's thin and pointless. I recommend going for the pizzas as they are the best value on the menu. $41 for a 12 oz. lobster - are you f'in with me? $26 for ribs? I will admit that in the bar area, there is a lot of eye candy and not the ditzy "I have to dance" type chicks. But I don't think I qualify just yet as an "elder gent".

Perhaps it was the euphoria of being back in my favorite city for the first time in a year, or the joy of once again being free of that land (read: Boston) where beers from west of the Hudson are unknown, but my experience at Tavern on Rush was phenomenal. Excellent outdoor seating perfect for watching locals and tourists alike as they stroll up and down Rush Street. Tasty burgers topped with fried egg. (Love you, Midwestern cuisine!! I realize fried eggs on burgers are hardly a novelty, but only in Chicago would I feel COMFORTABLE ordering such a thing.) And did I mention the beer? Were I fortunate enough to live in the Windy City, I would visit the Tavern with frequency...

nice outside seating.  great, full greek salad. yummy pinot noir. RUDE AND OBNOXIOUS HOSTESS CREW! I was tempted to walk back through the revolving doors after being rudely "helped" by  one of the sassy hostesses.  A perfect example of the classy staff: sighing, rolling her eyes and putting down her vogue/cosmo/whatev, and slowly tromping to take us to a table.  What a bummer it is to actually work.... Our actual server was cool though.

This is only a lunch review based on a sandwich. After battling the wind and rain on Michigan Ave, I knew I had enough because my shoes and socks were starting to get a bit moist (from the rain).  Walking around N. State St. and Rush Street, I decided to have lunch at Tavern on Rush. I was led to a table by a very pretty hostess to one of the many vacant tables.  It was around 1pm on a Thursday, and I thought the crowd was a bit light.  The lunch menu contained so much deliciousness that it was hard to decide on a choice, but I settled on the Rib Eye Steak Sandwich.  8 ounces of red meat sandwiched between fancy bread?  It's a good start.  I've had good rib-eye sandwiches in my day, was I going to be in for a treat or disappointment? The sandwich came with chipotle mayonnaise, sautéed onions, lettuce, cremini mushrooms and was served in a toasted onion ciabatta roll, which gave the occasional crunch.  I held out on the tomatoes and the fontina cheese.  My cooking preference for the meat was medium, and do you know what I got?  Medium.  That's right, the people in the kitchen got it right.  I'll award an extra star for that.  The meat was tender, well-marbled and full-flavored.  It got a little messy with the sauce dripping, onions and mushrooms creeping out, but that's how a good sandwich should be.  The meat and bread ratio was also right on.  As far as rib-eye sandwiches go, Tavern on Rush's version is my new favorite.  Man, the things you discover when you step out of the NJ/NYC area.

A Cosmo the size of two for $9 at the bar was enough to get my attention, but when I went upstairs to eat I was impressed.  With so many pricey restaurants not living up to their tabs, this restaurant was a refreshing surprise. The service, food, and drinks were wonderful. I was able to make changes to my order well after placing it without any problems or eye rolls. Just a smile and "certainly."  Yes, the bill can seep into the triple digit range, but I feel it was worth every penny.  My only wish is that I could afford to go back as often as I would like.

while the atmosphere is awesome, the servers are awful, rude and too busy trying to look good. they know nothing about the food or what kinds of liquor they have.  The appetizer we had (spinach artichoke dip) tasted like paste.  The place is a awesome to stop in and have a drink but only as a starting out point, not a place to spend your evening.

Great location and atmosphere and people watching. The food is just ok. Not great, not bad, and I usually enjoy each bite, but never just say "wow" when I eat my food. I like to say "wow."  The salads and pasta dishes are among their strong points. Go here for a good drink and good people watching. Fried calamari was good! (Not that I've ever had bad fried calamari).

Meat filled with sinew; deserts juvenile, hard and inedible; horseradish mashed potatoes with large chunks of horseradish (ugh); the food sucked. The service was five star, the wine acceptable and the view was nice by the window. In my opinion this place is just like the tourist traps on South Beach. They should be ashamed.

Easily the worst service I have ever had at any restaurant ever!  The waitress took 30 minutes to show up at our table the first time.  We ordered our drinks, and she did not return with them for another 30 minutes, and told us she would be right back to take our order.  Like clockwork, she did not return for another 30 minutes.  1.5 hours in, and we had no food.  She took our order, and then it took another 45 minutes for our food to show, in which time the waitress did not make one single stop at our table to see if we needed more drinks!  The food was ok, but probably seemed worse, because at this point, I had had enough.  After we were finished eating, we had been there for nearly three hours.  The waitress did not come back with our check until we had been sitting in the restaurant for what was now 3.5 hours.  Again, she did not stop at our table at any point while we were eating to see if we needed more drinks.  We ended up getting a bus boy to help us at the end.  When I left, I graciously told the woman working the hostess desk that it was the worst restaurant experience that I have ever had and that I was very dissappointed.  I said thank you and left since it was clear that she was also not interested in helping or even regarding my concern as relevant.  I will simply never eat here again for any reason whatsoever and will continue to let anyone I know of planning on going here that they should never go.

Very decent place. I was intending on going to Hugo's Frog Bar but the wait was 45 minutes and we were just too hungry. I expected the wait to be similar here as well, but we got a table in 5 minutes. The menu had a lot of variety, a lot of things I wanted to try, but I sticked to the ribeye. The steak was prepared very nicely, was very juicy, and everything that a ribeye should be. The filet mignon, however, was nothing special.
